instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER: What is SMC_ADAPTER? SMC_ADAPTER_EN is an abbreviation of SMC_ADAPTER_EN, which enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.ADAPTOR_EN: What is ADAPTOR_EN? This is a typo of SMC_ADAPTER_EN When you see ADAPTOR_EN, assume they meant to type SMC_ADAPTER_EN.

threads.title: 820-000165 <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Liquid damaged board not turning on.

3V42 = 3V42
Green / orange - yes
S5 rails are 3V3 / 5V

No <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>
No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>

Am I right on thinking that without <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> no S4 S3 S0 rails will turn on?

------

85W Apple charger.

threads.title: 820-000165 <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> was missing. Now powering. My question still stands about the <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER</SIGNAL> signal though.

Thanks!

threads.title: 820-000165 <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="MDY, post: 22899"]If <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER</SIGNAL> is 0V no green light. [/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> does [B]not[/B] affact charger green / orange.

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is sent out by the SMC and goes to[FONT=Courier][SIZE=12px] ACPRESENT[/SIZE] [/FONT]on the PCH. It's a signal to wake the PCH from deep Sx (under certain conditions).

In my case I had no <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

No <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> then no <SIGNAL>ADAPTOR_EN</SIGNAL> so no <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> / S4 / S3 / S0 signals from the PCH because <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> was not turning the PCH on......

I think I just answered my own question.

Please someone correct me if I'm wrong.

threads.title: 820-000165 <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Without <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> you get nothing above S5. This has nothing to do with onewire. <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is created by the SMC, it is created by the SMC [I]for other chips, [/I]not for itself.

Either way, good solve!
